deck: Hiro Mashima is the esteemed manga creator of Fairy Tail and Rave Master,
description:
History

Hiro Mashima was born May 3, 1977 and is a Manga artist and Creator. His notable Works are Rave Master and Fairy Tail. His creations are published in Kodansha's Weekly Manga Magazine respectively. He has worked on 8 different mangas as either a contributor or creator. He currently has a Younger Daughter.

Rave Master

The manga Rave Master follwed a boy named Haru (The Current Rave Master) as he quests to find the remanding Rave Stones along Plue and Elie. The manga lasted 296 chapters and ran from 1999 to 2005. The manga received positive reviews yet it wasnt widely popular though it had a fanbase. It earned a 3/4 stars form Del Rey magazine stating it had a shaky story at 1st but generally picked up after the first story arc.

Fairy Tail

Fairy Tail is an ongoing manga since Aug 23, 2006. The manga is being published by Kodansha and the story revolves around Lucy ,Natsu and their companions of Fairy Tail as they go on many adventures. The Manga is very well received as it once marked the top ten Mangas of the year. About.com's Deb Aoki listed as the best Shonen of 2008. It is also the winner of the Kodansha Manga Award for Shonen manga of 2009. The Society for the Promotion of Japanese Animations Industry awarded it best comedy Manga of 2009.

Other Works

  • Plue's Dog Diaries (2002-2007)
  • Mashima-en Vol.1 & 2 (2003)
  • Monster Soul (2006-2007)
  • Monster Hunter Orage (2008-2009)
  • Sangokushi Taisen card illustration
  • Respect Gundam contribution

Fun Facts:

  • Each main character of his mangas are named after a season:
    • Rave Master (Haru = Spring)
    • Fairy Tail (Natsu = Summer)
    • Monster Soul (Aki = Autumn)
    • Monster Hunter Orage (Shiki = Four Seasons)
  • When Asked about Gray Fullbuster's habit of stripping at SDCC, he replied that it was a habit of his own.
  • He originally planned for Fairy Tail to last only 10 volumes but that changed due to both Fan base and him personally wanting to continue drawing the manga.
name: Hiro Mashima

deck: Os Petroli is talented rising artist that lives in Santa Fe, Argentina.  He uses a utilitarian storytelling art style that is best shown in "The Skyrocket" from an independent comic book publisher in Virginia.
description: A member of http://www.deviantART.com/, Petroli found a ad from a writer in Viriginia Beach on the website in search of an artist.  Petroli answered the call, and together with creator Mike Federali, they started the comic The Skyrocket published by an small, independent comic book publisher in 2010.
name: Osmar Petroli

description:
Andy Belanger is a comic artist and illustrator based out of Montreal, Quebec. He is a member of Studio Lounak along with Becky Cloonan, Karl Kerschl, and Serge Lapointe.

Belanger hails originally from Toronto, where he shared a studio with Scott Hepburn, Kalman Andrasofszky, Ramón Pérez and Willow Dawson.
name: Andy Belanger

deck: Kagan McLeod has been illustrating for magazines, newspapers and design firms since 1999, after graduating from Sheridan College's illustration program. He began work as a staff artist for Canada’s National Post newspaper, and has since had work published in magazines around the world. He's the co-creator of Kaptara with Chip Zdarsky and creator of Infinite Kung-Fu.
description:
Kagan McLeod has worked mainly in newspapers and magazines as an illustrator since 1999. His illustrations have been seen in publications such as Entertainment Weekly, Fast Company, Glamour, GQ, Men’s Health, Newsweek, People, Sports Illustrated and Time. He has been recognized in Communication Arts and American Illustration, as well as Lurzer Archive’s 200 Best Illustrator’s Worldwide.

In 2000, he began self-publishing Infinite Kung Fu locally, then internationally with Diamond Distributors in 2002. After seven issues, Kagan teamed up with Top Shelf Productions to collect the complete work in one volume with over 200 never-before-seen pages, which were finally completed in 2011. He lives in Toronto with his wife, two daughters and hound dog, Buddy.
name: Kagan McLeod

deck: Scottish author and physician best known as the creator of Sherlock Holmes
description:
For the page about the character based on the author, see Arthur Conan Doyle 

Career

Conan Doyle had his first story published in 1879, and began writing in earnest in 1882, though he had difficulty getting his work published. In 1886 his story A Study in Scarlet, the first appearance of his most famous character, Sherlock Holmes, was published. This novel proved popular, and he was commissioned to continue telling the adventures of Holmes. In 1893, tired of writing Holmes and wishing to dedicate himself to his other works, he wrote the death of the character in the story "The Final Problem". The detective's death prompted public outcry, and subsequent works achieved little success. In 1901 he wrote The Hound of the Baskervilles, a Holmes story set before the fatal encounter at the Reichenbach Falls. In 1903 he brought the character back to life in the first short story in ten years. In total he wrote 56 short stories and four novels based on Holmes. Most of these were published in the Strand Magazine. He is also notable for his historical fiction novels, which he began work on in 1888 and of which he published seven, his non-fiction works, on which he began work in 1900 and published fourteen, and his Challenger stories, which he began work on in 1912 and of which he published three novels and two short stories. He also published numerous other works, including plays, novels and short stories in a variety of genres. 

Personal Life

Born in 1858, Conan Doyle had an occasionally difficult and tumultuous upbringing due to his father's alcoholism. Nonetheless, he enjoyed good schooling due to the intervention of wealthy relatives. In 1876 he began attending the University of Edinburgh, where he studied medicine and became acquainted with the man who would later provide the model for Sherlock Holmes, Joseph Bell. He graduated in 1881, and found employment as a ship's surgeon before opening his own practice. In 1885 he married Louisa Hawkins, with whom he had two children. Louisa died in 1906. He married Jean Elizabeth Leckie the following year, and together the couple had three children. He predeceased his second wife, suffering a heart attack on July 7th, 1930 at the age of 71.
name: Arthur Conan Doyle

deck: Steven S. DeKnight is an American television screenwriter, producer, and director, best known for working on Smallville, Buffy the Vampire Slayer, and Angel. He has also written "Swell", a story in the Buffy the Vampire Slayer season eight comic series, and served as a consulting producer on Joss Whedon's television series Dollhouse. DeKnight is currently an executive producer and head writer of Starz series Spartacus: Blood and Sand.
name: Steven S. Deknight

deck: Will Jacobs (born 1955) is an American comics and humor writer. He was a coauthor with Gerard Jones on The Beaver Papers, The Comic Book Heroes, and the comic book The Trouble with Girls (1987-1993).  He was a contributor to National Lampoon magazine and various DC Comics. Jacobs left professional writing in the 1990s to start a used and antiquarian book service, Avalon Books. He co-wrote with Jones The Comic Book Heroes, a book dedicated to the history of the American comic book industry from the Silver Ag
name: Will Jacobs

deck:
Marvin Perry Mann began his comics career inking The Trouble With Girls (Malibu Graphics). Other titles included Ape City, Lizard Lady and Flesh Gordon. 
Leaving comics for almost a decade he learned woodworking and furniture design, and then digital 3d modeling and animation. He returned to comics in 2002.
name: Marvin Perry Mann

description:
Other Media

Novels

G.I. Joe: Tales From the Cobra Wars

G.I. Joe: Tales from the Cobra Wars is an action-packed collection of all-original prose stories. Flint, Scarlett, Destro, the Baroness; they're all here as the ongoing war between G.I. JOE and Cobra is depicted from every angel. This trade paperback presents eight novella-length tales, penned by today's leading crime and thriller writers, such as Jonathan Maberry, Duane Swierczynski , Chuck Dixon, and Dennis Tafoya. Cobra Wars is edited by Max Brooks, who also supplies a new story, and features new illustrations for each story.
  • Written By: Various, Anthology
  • Publisher: IDW
  • ISBN-10: 1600108814

World War Z: An Oral History of the Zombie War

The zombie war came unthinkably close to eradicating humanity. Max Brooks, driven by the urgency of preserving the acid-etched first-hand experiences of the survivors from those apocalyptic years, traveled across the United States of America and throughout the world, from decimated cities that once teemed with upwards of thirty million souls to the most remote and inhospitable areas of the planet. He recorded the testimony of men, women, and sometimes children who cam face-to-face with the living, or at least the undead, hell of that dreadful time. World War Z is the result. Never before have we had access to a document that so powerfully conveys the depth of fear and horror, and also the ineradicable spirit of resistance, that gripped human society through the plague years.
Ranging from the now infamous village of New Dachang in the United Federation of China, where the epidemiological trail began with the twelve-year-old Patient Zero, to the unnamed northern forests where untold numbers sought a terrible and temporary refuge in the cold, to the United States of Southern Africa, where the Redeker Plan provided hope for humanity at an unspeakable price, to the west-of-the-Rockies redoubt where the North American tide finally started to turn, this invaluable chronicle reflects the full scope and duration of the Zombie War.
Most of all, the book captures with haunting immediacy the human dimension of this epochal event. Facing the often raw and vivid nature of these personal accounts requires a degree of courage on the part of the reader, but the effort is invaluable because, as Mr. Brooks says in his introduction, "By excluding the human factor, aren't we risking the kind of personal detachment from history that may, heaven forbid, lead us one day to repeat it? And in the end, isn't the human factor the only true difference between us and the enemy we now refer to as 'the living dead'?"
  • Publisher: Crown Publishers (2006)
  • ISBN: 0-307-34660-9

The Zombie Survival Guide: Complete Protection from the Living Dead

Top 10 Lessons For Surviving A Zombie Attack
  1. Organize before they rise!
  2. They Feel no fear, why should you?
  3. Use your head: cut off theirs.
  4. Blades don't need reloading.
  5. Ideal protection = tight clothes, short hair.
  6. Get up the staircase, then destroy it.
  7. Get out of the car, get onto the bike.
  8. Keep moving, keep lo, keep quiet, keep alert!
  9. No place is safe, only safer.
  10. Th zombies may be gone, but the threat lives on.
Don't be carefree and foolish with your most precious asset-- life. This book is your key to survival against the hordes of undead who may be stalking you right now without your even knowing it. The Zombie Survival Guid offers complete protection through trusted, proven tips for safeguarding yourself and your loved ones against the living dead. It is a book that can save your life.
  • Publisher: Three Rivers Press (2003)
  • ISBN: 1-4000-4962-8
name: Max Brooks

deck: Writer best known for his work on the TV series "Brothers & Sisters".
description:
Career

Peter got his break from DC where he wrote several Batman related one-shots. He took over Gotham City Sirens from Paul Dini as well, marking his first On-going series written. He also co-wrote Anti with Gale Anne Hurd. The comic released on Free Comic Book Day 2012 by 12-Gauge Comics.

He is also known for his writing for several TV series, most notably Brothers & Sisters and Hellcats. He also directed a short film, THINK TANK.

Personal Life

Peter is married and is currently working on new projects. He went to Amherst College, graduating with degrees in Philosophy and Modern European History. He currently lives in Los Angeles, California.
name: Peter Calloway

deck: Ron Kieser is a comic book colorist from Uniques, Uniques Tales, After the Fire, and Rainbow in the Dark.  Since November 2007 Ron has been working as a comic flat colorist on various comics and graphic novels.
description:
From Ron:
 
Ever since November 2007 I have been working as a color flat artist for the comic "The Uniques" by Adam Withers and Comfort Love, and have been enjoying every moment of it. With my 2.5 years of doing work for them, they referred me to another artist Jon Alderink to work on some pages for the IDW Publishing graphic novel "After The Fire", which is available for pre-order now. I am about to start a new project, but until it's officially announced, I have to keep quiet, but it will be a blast!

As for being a flat artist, my job is to take the inks done for the pages and apply the base colors to each page before they get the toning done. For the most part there are solid colors chosen for the main characters, but I also choose appropriate colors for the rest of the surrounding areas, along with making sure the right objects are colored properly, and not as part of a different object. Different techniques are used depending on the style of the page and comic, and sometimes multiple techniques must be used even on the same page, depending on the situation. Judgment is a very important part of the process, along with being able to not only complete a page accurately, but in a timely manner as well, making for the most efficiency, which in turn leads to more work in a shorter time.

It's a fun process, and pages can range from incredibly simple to multiple hours of detail oriented coloring. Through my experience I have created color tools to increase the efficiency of not only myself but to help fellow colorists. It's been a valuable experience and am happy to be getting paid for something I love doing, especially with the challenge of constantly trying to improve my speed and accuracy making for more impressive comics.
name: Ron Kieser
